title: Will the Scottish National Party win a majority of seats in the next Scottish Parliament election?
preds: Albe seems to be a busted flush and Labour and the Tories are swapping votes between themselves. However, a lot of seats are maginal so I am cautiously optimistic that the answer will be yes.

Last forecast: Sinking or swimming at this point on an SNP majority. FWIW the most recent two polls listed in the link are higher for SNP than the previous iterations: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Opinion_polling_for_the_2021_Scottish_Parliament_election https://www.predictit.org/markets/detail/7128/How-many-seats-will-the-SNP-win-in-Scotland's-next-election

Brexit is highly unpopular in Scotland. Johnson has been blatantly rude about Scottish politicians. And, like most of the other nations in the UK, Scotland is tired of seeing the things they want to do nixed by the Conservative government. Labor is not much of a factor in these elections anymore.
2/3s feels right, will put neck out and say they will get 65 exact but error margin slim.

Thanks to @jayb (https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1273011) for some useful, albeit conflicting info, and @Juliabizz (https://bit.ly/3tmK10K) and @Mark_T (https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1272914) As most forecasters and polls seem to agree, this is going to be a close call. I am erring on the side the SNP will not get a majority because the Greens will pick up many of the now disillusioned ex-SNP voters. Hence, Holyrood will have a pro-indy balance which may still make things uncomfortable for BoJo but less so than is Sturgeon wins an outright majority. I am also being influenced a bit by Prof Curtice's record (which @SE_Meyer is / was also relying on?)

Polling (Savanta ComRes vs YouGov, Ipsos Mori etc.) appears unreliable as a hard indicator for this question's razor thin margin call of "majority or not" so it should only be seen as a measure of "it'll be really close" (within 1 or 2 seats either way) [1 and 2].  Its hard to find an unbiased poll commissioned by the papers on this issue (the Herald and The Scotsman appear to have a bias towards unionism and anti independence so their Savanta ComRes polling (and its fairly minuscule scope) should be taken with a pinch of salt I'd suggest) but their assessments can be blended with other, more qualitative factors to base a half decent probability estimate on (with a fairly objective degree of confidence).  So how do you build a probability forecast on anything beyond 50/50 (which is arguably as far as the split and not entirely unbiased polling gets you to for the "majority" question)?  Other factors I think are worth taking into consideration at this late stage: 1.  Debate performance appeared stable [3] and unlikely to move the needle in any fundamental way, but Sturgeon's firm and repeated declaration that a "wild cat" referendum was off the cards (and that an Indy Ref would only be called at a responsible time once economic stability was achieved) appeared to be a last minute appeal to the undecided or gently Indy AND non-Indy leaning voters that the SNP could be trusted as the responsible, balanced, "centre ground" vote (on the Indy issue anyway) that supported a democratic decision on the issue at "the right and responsible time". 2.  Sturgeon's calculation appears to be that this group is worth a punt at persuading and that their benefit trumps any possible loss of support from the hard line Indy vote (that they may feel will more likely vote Alba or Green at this point anyway or will not be likely to jump ship in large numbers, still seeing the SNP as their best chance for what they want despite the softened approach to Independence). Does this increase or decrease the chance of a majority?  Hard to say definitively (and even harder to say if the pitch will land), but the mollification of their Indy line is an interesting path to see them take that may be designed at the last second to spoke the Conservative messaging wheel and allay fears of more reasonable voters.  I think this gives a slight increase in probability of a majority and with some increased confidence given the amount of internal opinion polling that probably went into this messaging pitch. 3.  We should also factor in BJ's, Westminster's and the Tory Government's current popularity north of the border into this question (not good, but how much that drives any "F*** You, Jimmy!" voting contribution is also hard to determine with high confidence).  Whilst BJ's increasingly public corruption and amoral governance does not appear to have fundamentally altered voter intentions south of the border (a depressing measure of modern British ethical, moral and honour based leadership) that may not be true North of the Border with a stronger anti-Brexit crowd, and freshly Brexit scarred fishing industry and a generally stronger "anti-Westminster" (and "anti-Tory fop") sentiment at the best of times.  Again, a (slight) contribution to the rise above the 50/50 polling baseline I feel is warranted against this factor. I fell like the crowd has probably hit the correct mark on this probability estimate in the last few days (having been perhaps fairly over confident up until this last week or so) and I'm happy to go a little above based on my personal weighting of the factors described above. Revising down inline with the odds, and reflecting the effectiveness of media operations.

Revising my prediction upwards. There seems to have been an increase in support for the SNP in the last few days which I wasn't expecting. Furthermore there is a record breaking amount of people registering to vote, with the areas seeing the biggest increase being the areas with large non UK populations (who have recently been enfranchised and typically are more pro independence/SNP than those born within Scotland).

Full Forecast: https://globalguessing.com/metaculus-mondays-vol13/ Unfortunately for the SNP, the massive lead they enjoyed during the peak of the British pandemic appears to have abated as the country has gotten the pandemic mostly under control (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Opinion_polling_for_the_2021_Scottish_Parliament_election#/media/File:Opinion_polling_for_the_next_Scottish_Parliament_election_(regional_vote).png). At the same time the SNP has seen a dip in the polls, so too has support for Scottish independence (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Wiki_Scots_Indep_V6_new_format.pdf). According to The New Statemen's election model, the SNP are forecasted to receive 37% of the vote and win 62 seats–a net loss of one seat and just short of the 65 needed for a majority (https://www.newstatesman.com/politics/scotland/2021/04/scottish-independence-poll-tracker-will-scotland-vote-leave-uk) And based on our election model (https://globalguessing.com/tag/elections/), the SNP have a 30% likelihood of a majority.

So what has changed?   Support for SNP based on Politico's poll of polls has slightly declined, based on which I had downgraded the prob by a couple of points. As of Apr 30.  ~ 48% (73 single-member constituency seats) & 37% (56 regional list seats) 
As of Mar 31 ~ 49% (73 single-member constituency seats)  & 40% (56 regional list seats)  Interestingly in the same time period, a very slight majority now oppose the referendum - which may correlate with the drop in support for SNP.  Of course, we don't know much polling error we should expect- given that the pollsters would have operated under Covid-19 conditions.

Multiple recent polls suggesting drop in SNP support. Seems increasingly unlikely they will have an absolute majority of 65 seats although still within margin of error. https://www.scotsman.com/news/politics/scottish-election-2021-polling-expert-says-snp-majority-on-a-knife-edge-3215752 https://www.scotsman.com/news/politics/worst-polling-for-yes-since-2019-as-snp-support-continues-to-drop-poll-shows-3218102 https://www.scotsman.com/news/politics/scottish-election-2021-alex-salmonds-party-on-track-to-win-eight-seats-poll-suggests-3215409 https://ballotbox.scot/bmg-april-2021

Moving down a little in the final week with the Greens potentially eating enough of the SNP's vote to steal the crown of a majority from them (whilst still leaving a collective majority for independence as part of the aforementioned "F You!" vote). The nature of the more proportional voting system in Scotland, the spread of the independence vote amongst three parties (although Alba at this stage still hasn't breached much beyond "Monster Raving Loony" levels) and staining caused by the recent Sturgeon / Salmond fiasco all play the odds downwards, whilst Boris' own recent scandals (watch for more to come this next week), the impact of Brexit on Scotland fisheries (with recent announcements about the lack of a Norway deal not helping [4]) and the more general opportunity to say "F You!" to the scruffy, entitled fop down south all play against.  As a counter, we shouldn't disregard the effect the massive social media influence machine that has served Boris so well in recent past being pumped furiously to dissuade some voters and persuade others [1 & 2].  Bookies are apparently giving 8/11 odds (roughly translated as 58% probability) for an SNP majority and 11/10 (or 69%) for the SNP to fall short of a majority with days to go [3], and I'd be surprised if the Cummings & Gove assassination team haven't got something up their sleeve in this last week to try and put another dent in Boris' rapidly tarnishing armour (although its worth noting that current polls suggest today's UK voter doesn't have as much of a problem with rampant corruption and self dealing as some might have hoped!).  As such, I think there's plenty still to play for an the debate on the 4th promises to be feisty. Leaning to one side of the fence to lower the SNP's odds to 48%. The rise of the Green Party is another notable force. The Greens are pro-independence but their primary message about the environment, climate, nature is resonating across lines. A vote for the Greens is a vote lost for the SNP.  From the BBC's political correspondent in Scotland (https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-scotland-scotland-politics-56744858)
"There has been much focus on the Green position on the constitution, given their potentially pivotal role in creating a pro-independence majority at Holyrood. It was certainly the subject of many of the questions at the manifesto launch. However, based on the manifesto alone, the subject is far from the top of the Green list of priorities - accounting for only two of the 96 pages"

The latest polls show a loss of momentum with the political parties. There has been a rise in profile for the new Labour leader, Anas Sarwar and is proving to be popular. Events in Westminster have overshadowed this election and Sir John Curtice appears to backing off from his two seat majority of a few days ago. The Indy Ref vote also appears to be diminishing from its 50%  ‘Yes’ vote.

The polls seem to indicate it is close but central expectation should be no majority for SNP. One example: https://ballotbox.scot/ To me normally that would indicate something like 33 - 49% chance. I.e. 1/3rd chance of a major polling miss and then when very close it gets to even a minor miss in their favour helping. Other sources seem to be more bullish on snp, I.e crowd forecast and to an extent betting markets are at least the top end of the range https://www.oddschecker.com/politics/british-politics/scottish-politics/scottish-election-2021-snp-majority The fact that the poll trends shows they probably went from slightly above central case to slightly below 50/50 over the last weeks does not really mean much to me. You could argue reversion to mean or momentum against them. I also think views are being impacted by the wider question of how much support there is for independence and will there be another referendum or at least a serious push for one. Honestly I would probably be 45% but I am far enough away from the consensus anyway, so going for 50%
That seems pretty obvious. The fallout from Covid and brexit will lead to independence and for that stands the SNP.

Could definitely go either way, and it will be very close to the required 65 seats whichever side it falls on. If you take the polls at their word then it is very difficult to justify assigning over 50% on this.

Keeping my prediction the same. The only movement in the polls in the last month seems to be a slight reduction in support for the SNP on the constitutioncy, and a large shift towards the greens on the all important list. Furthermore I am still confident that SNP supporters will turn out slightly less on the day. In part due to a lack of enthusiasm for an increasingly lackluster government (for many independence is the only motivation to still vote for them) but also due to the historical turn out trends amongst the demographics which the SNP gets most of its support. Going by the granularity of the polling it seems that the most motivated by the independence issue isn't young Independence supporters, it's old supporters of the Union. Therefore the increased talk of another ref may have a greater positive impact on those voting for unionist parties than it does amongst much of the SNP vote base. Turnout for Holyrood elections is typically quite low at around 55% (compared to 65-70% amongst the Scottish electorate for Westminster elections). I suspect we will see a turnout comparable to a UK wide election next week due to the increased media attention over its labeling as a precursor to indeyref 2, and the huge increase in postal ballots. On this last point I am unsure if and how this could effect the result. Will postal votes be spread equally, or will they increase the turnout for any particular side? For this uncertainty I have not reduced the likelihood below my previous prediction. I am new to forecasting, but feel the communities rating on this question is too high. Going beyond bookies odds and indeed much recent polling.  I would suggest a look at the polling in the run up for the 2016 election (which was noticeably higher than now) and comparing it to what they got in the day. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Opinion_polling_for_the_2016_Scottish_Parliament_election

And back up again with the release of the Ipsos Mori poll on Scottish Elections [1] and the “Tarring and feathering" of the Clown Prince south of the wall not showing any signs of abatement any time soon. I don't think even for a second the timing of this is in any way a coincidence.  Cummings has been quietly seething and waiting for his moment to bite from the shadows, and it also seems likely that the modern day Brutus that is Gove also smells sufficient blood in the water to start manoeuvring.   All this appears to be hitting  the conservatives [2] as much as the Clown Prince himself [3] which, from the perspective of the Scottish elections, may act both as a dissuader for non-tribal & ethically conscious Tory voters AND as an animator  for those Scots increasingly disgusted with the current UK Governments behaviour and looking to send a powerful message of rebuke (with a vote for the SNP likely to be seen as the loudest megaphone through which to broadcast it).  The "F You!" vote has always been hard to measure through traditional polling techniques (as those being polled tend to use the phrase "liberally" when being asked political questions!) but has also been responsible for some of the most impactful referenda and election results of the last decade. Deliberately stayed away from this for a few weeks so as to not overreact to individual events.  Now recalibrated forecast from scratch based on current data and (hopefully) correctly weighted historical events. Probability still feels in the SNPs favour, but their grasp of a majority result appears to have loosened somewhat.  The timings of the latest results appear to set a course for what may happen on the day.  The conservatives have little to offer except to push voter dissuasion in the hope of profiting from a reduced turn out, and whilst labour appear to be on the rise from the FT's poll [1] that could be simple reactionary polling rather than a true reflection of on the day voting intention. That said, Cummings appears to be enjoying the limelight again and I can't believe what he's been stirring in the last 48 hours is the best he has on the Clown Prince.  A few more suitably egregious demonstrations of corruption and self interest (although how many more are needed is in itself a telling indicator of lethargic British morality!) and Scots may vote for the SNP just to stick it to the grubby, corrupt little "denizen at No 10". It is entirely plausible to believe that Scots will vote for the SNP in May just to stick it to BoJo, London and England in general only to then vote against independence if and when a vote comes up and "things get real".  I think looking at Independence vote appetite as an indicator of May voting intentions may miss a few nuances and shades of grey in voting behaviour for a disgruntled, animated and generally mistrustful electorate. As has been pointed out by various forecasters and news articles, the Scottish electoral system is largely designed in a manner that will not produce a majority. And as @Tolga (https://bit.ly/3arU5yE) pointed out, two polls are showing SNP some seats short of a majority. Albeit there is likely to be a majority of pro-independence seats in Holyrood, most likely either with or without a formal coalition with the greens (https://bit.ly/3sE6Ah0), in terms of this question, or my interpretation thereof, the SNP would not have a majority of seats filled my SNP members. Something that has intrigued me about this election is why the SNP seems to be riding so high in many polls when I try to look objectively at the party's record over 14 years in office, either as a majority or in the minority with support of Greens and Lib Dems (in some cases)? Admittedly, a probably biased article out of London gives a very damning picture of SNP lack of ability to govern. See for yourself here; https://bit.ly/3dBU4Kt. The seventy odd page report linked in this article is equally damning. However, where there is some smoke, there must be some fire. Some of the issues such as ferries, hospitals, drug deaths, steel and aluminum smelters etc seem to crop up in other articles or in the current campaigning. Thus, on the basis of this information and the polls referred to by @Tolga, I am reducing my probability. While I appreciate that independence is a major driver in the current election campaign I find it difficult to believe that a significant majority of Scots voters will simply ignore some cold economic and governance truths in the current pandemic environment and after the recent Salmond debacle, which also cost Scottish taxpayers dearly, in order to test the water and see of Johnson will grant another independence referendum.

SNP will do well in terms of constituency votes / seats.   Tory sleaze and Labour fence sitting will lead to that outcome.   Question is around the Regional seats then.   The anti-indy coalition will target those votes to restrict the power of SNP to get a (big) majority.

@Juliabizz Sturgeon seems intent on dodging the economic reality and cost of independence? Or perhaps, relying on emotional appeal to the converted and hoping to pull the wool over the eyes of some wavering voters that may be inclined to vote for independence? See what you think? https://youtu.be/766HnfIIl-k & https://bit.ly/3eo2rJ9. Betfair is often as accurate as opinion polls but yet another 'unrecorded' ministerial meeting isn't likely to do SNP's reputation much good; https://bit.ly/3ahe5UV Unrecorded meetings aside, will the reality of the SNP's guarantees to Gupta / Greensil that will cost the taxpayer hundreds of millions be an issue for voters? I would have expected it to be so but apparently it's not an issue.  Trying to avoid any form of bias and not having any interests of any kind in Scotland, the SNP does not seem to have a record in the last 14 years which would persuade me to vote for them. That being the case, the party does come over as a one topic party; independence, independence and independence. It strikes me that possibly the opportunity for independence has slipped past and as @Superduperuser suggests, the union supporting voter is possibly keeping a low profile for now and may surprise on the day.  The BBC summary of poll of polls gives the SNP a potential of a 9 seat majority; https://bbc.in/32lAY53 @Mark_T points out, the "fragility of the question’s requirement for a majority win as opposed to simply having the most seats." leaves some room for wrangling and debate. In one sense, perhaps the devil in the detail is "Will the Scottish National Party win a majority of seats...." which I interpret as being the SNP without the support of Greens / Lib Dems or any others. As this BBC article, https://bbc.in/3dpg0IX, clarifies, the electoral system is a bit convoluted and is indeed unlikely to result in a clear majority. Thus, for now, I will go with the crowd and see how things evolve in the coming weeks.

Remaining on the fence. Betting odds see SNP coming up just short. https://www.betfair.com/sport/politics/scottish-parliament-election/12312083/snp-majority-2021-scottish-parliament-election/924.255883282

Downgrading slightly based on latest polling. Still think an SNP majority is the most likely outcome, based largely on leadership polling. Nicola Sturgeon remains extremely popular. Like @Tolga I am surprised the crowd forecast has remained as consistently high as it has. STV is designed to produce non-majority governments.

Second poll in a row that has the SNP short of a majority, this time 2 seats short.

The SNP is on track to win 71 of 129 seats, further to a Scotsman newspaper poll in mid-January, a gain of 8 seats from its 2016 election result.[1]  About 57% of Scottish voters favor independence, according to the same polling snapshot.  SNP leader Nicola Sturgeon has promised to push for another referendum if they win a majority.  The Scottish parliamentary system through its so-called "Additional Member System" creates a much closer and more direct relationship to public opinion in proportionally allocating seats than the Westminster system of "first past the post."[2]  In this way, it seems to me, that many Scottish voters see a direct connection between voting SNP and rejecting the UK government's chaos and bungling of Brexit and COVID under Boris Johnson.  The AMS method makes public opinion a much more reliable gauge of the outcome than in "first past the post" systems, in my view.  It is hard to imagine a scenario where the UK government is able to implement Brexit in a way that mollifies public opinion now that the negative implications of Brexit for everyday life are becoming more clear with each day.  A small, mundane example: UK visitors to EU will pay a non-EU interchange fee that is five times the amount they paid on purchases in EU territories before Brexit.[3]  The media has extensively covered the much larger issues with food, medicine, transportation, and security.  COVID and the Johnson government's perceived callousness will still be a fresh wound for all in the UK in May, but especially for Scottish nationalism.  Especially if the majority of Scots believe independence will allow them to re-enter the EU, which the majority now favor, the number of seats in play might increase further still. Those who know me on here will know that I deliberately avoid making 100% forecasts out of principle: very few things can be genuinely / objectively / empirically referred to as "certain", even fewer things in politics and even fewer things again in today's upside down world. That said, if there was ever a certainty to be found in today's turbulent UK politics, this question has it.  There is nothing present in the (currently) United Kingdom governments portfolio of "successes" that offers the Scottish people any reason to move away from the SNP and towards Conservatives.  With the after-taste of Corbyn's tacit support for Brexit and leadership failures in combating BJ's populist rise to power still lingering on the Labour Party there really are no other viable alternatives to the SNP for Scottish people. When combined with the consistently strong performance of the SNP in the last several elections...
